segment.source: Network security Restrict NTLM Audit incoming NTLM traffic (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security Restrict NTLM Audit incoming NTLM traffic (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network Security Restrict NTLM Audit incoming NTLM traffic security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network Security Restrict NTLM Audit incoming NTLM traffic security policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic
segment.target: Network security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic security policy setting.

segment.source: The Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic policy setting allows you to audit incoming NTLM traffic.
segment.target: The Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic policy setting allows you to audit incoming NTLM traffic.

segment.source: When this audit policy is enabled within Group Policy, it is enforced on any server where that Group Policy is distributed.
segment.target: When this audit policy is enabled within Group Policy, it is enforced on any server where that Group Policy is distributed.

segment.source: The events will be recorded in the operational event log located in Applications and Services LogMicrosoftWindowsNTLM.
segment.target: The events will be recorded in the operational event log located in Applications and Services LogMicrosoftWindowsNTLM.

segment.source: Using an audit event collection system can help you collect the events for analysis more efficiently.
segment.target: Using an audit event collection system can help you collect the events for analysis more efficiently.

segment.source: When you enable this policy on a server, only authentication traffic to that server will be logged.
segment.target: When you enable this policy on a server, only authentication traffic to that server will be logged.

segment.source: When you enable this audit policy, it functions in the same way as the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy, but it does not actually block any traffic.
segment.target: When you enable this audit policy, it functions in the same way as the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy, but it does not actually block any traffic.

segment.source: Therefore, you can use it effectively to understand the authentication traffic in your environment, and when you are ready to block that traffic, you can enable the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy setting and select Deny all accounts or Deny all domain accounts.
segment.target: Therefore, you can use it effectively to understand the authentication traffic in your environment, and when you are ready to block that traffic, you can enable the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy setting and select Deny all accounts or Deny all domain accounts.

segment.source: The server on which this policy is set will not log events for incoming NTLM traffic.
segment.target: The server on which this policy is set will not log events for incoming NTLM traffic.

segment.source: The server on which this policy is set will log events for NTLM pass-through authentication requests only for accounts in the domain that would be blocked when the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy setting is set to Deny all domain accounts.
segment.target: The server on which this policy is set will log events for NTLM pass-through authentication requests only for accounts in the domain that would be blocked when the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy setting is set to Deny all domain accounts.

segment.source: The server on which this policy is set will log events for all NTLM authentication requests that would be blocked when the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy setting is set to Deny all accounts.
segment.target: The server on which this policy is set will log events for all NTLM authentication requests that would be blocked when the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Incoming NTLM traffic policy setting is set to Deny all accounts.

segment.source: This is the same as Disable, and it results in no auditing of NTLM traffic.
segment.target: This is the same as Disable, and it results in no auditing of NTLM traffic.

segment.source: Depending on your environment and the duration of your testing, monitor the log size regularly.
segment.target: Depending on your environment and the duration of your testing, monitor the log size regularly.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: This section describes different features and tools available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes different features and tools available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a restart when saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a restart when saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Setting and deploying this policy using Group Policy takes precedence over the setting on the local device.
segment.target: Setting and deploying this policy using Group Policy takes precedence over the setting on the local device.

segment.source: If the Group Policy is set to Not Configured, local settings will apply.
segment.target: If the Group Policy is set to Not Configured, local settings will apply.

segment.source: View the operational event log to see if this policy is functioning as intended.
segment.target: View the operational event log to see if this policy is functioning as intended.

segment.source: Audit and block events are recorded on this computer in the operational event log located in Applications and Services LogMicrosoftWindowsNTLM.
segment.target: Audit and block events are recorded on this computer in the operational event log located in Applications and Services LogMicrosoftWindowsNTLM.

segment.source: Using an audit event collection system can help you collect the events for analysis more efficiently.
segment.target: Using an audit event collection system can help you collect the events for analysis more efficiently.

segment.source: There are no security audit event policies that can be configured to view output from this policy.
segment.target: There are no security audit event policies that can be configured to view output from this policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: NTLM and NTLMv2 authentication is vulnerable to a variety of malicious attacks, including SMB relay, man-in-the-middle attacks, and brute force attacks.
segment.target: NTLM and NTLMv2 authentication is vulnerable to a variety of malicious attacks, including SMB relay, man-in-the-middle attacks, and brute force attacks.

segment.source: Reducing and eliminating NTLM authentication from your environment forces the Windows operating system to use more secure protocols, such as the Kerberos version 5 protocol, or different authentication mechanisms, such as smart cards.
segment.target: Reducing and eliminating NTLM authentication from your environment forces the Windows operating system to use more secure protocols, such as the Kerberos version 5 protocol, or different authentication mechanisms, such as smart cards.

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting will reveal through logging which servers and client computers within your network or domain handle NTLM traffic.
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting will reveal through logging which servers and client computers within your network or domain handle NTLM traffic.

segment.source: The identity of these devices can be used in malicious ways if NTLM authentication traffic is compromised.
segment.target: The identity of these devices can be used in malicious ways if NTLM authentication traffic is compromised.

segment.source: The policy setting does not prevent or mitigate any vulnerability because it is for audit purposes only.
segment.target: The policy setting does not prevent or mitigate any vulnerability because it is for audit purposes only.

segment.source: Restrict access to the log files when this policy setting is enabled in your production environment.
segment.target: Restrict access to the log files when this policy setting is enabled in your production environment.

segment.source: If you do not enable or configure this policy setting, no NTLM authentication traffic information will be logged.
segment.target: If you do not enable or configure this policy setting, no NTLM authentication traffic information will be logged.

segment.source: If you do enable this policy setting, only auditing functions will occur; no security enhancements will be implemented.
segment.target: If you do enable this policy setting, only auditing functions will occur; no security enhancements will be implemented.
